summary: This document is an email chain from November 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office staff discussing the technical process of generating redacted reports from Jeffrey Epstein's electronic devices (phones and iPads) for a privilege review. The emails detail issues with file generation, the removal of potentially privileged (PP) materials, and coordination to meet discovery deadlines.

persons.name: Enrique
persons.role: Investigative Analyst or staff assisting with data extraction
persons.context: Mentioned as working on generating reports from Epstein's devices, specifically noted for spending a whole day on device 1B71.

persons.name: Lisa
persons.context: Requests setup of a shared directory for the privilege review and is a recipient of a drive containing Epstein device data.

persons.name: Elisabeth
persons.context: Scheduled to review device extractions for privileged materials once they are made available.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of a chat from device 1884 that was removed as potentially privileged (PP) material.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The data being reviewed is extracted from his phones and iPads as part of a privilege review process.

connections.description: A chat between Epstein and Darren Indyke was found on device 1884 and flagged as potentially privileged material.
Both are U.S. Attorney's Office staff coordinating on the technical aspects of the Epstein device review and data transfer.

events.title: Discovery deadline
events.description: Mentioned as the deadline by which responsive materials from the Epstein device review need to be prepared for production.

events.title: Drive shipment to Monday
events.description: A drive containing data from Epstein's devices was copied and sent via FedEx, expected to arrive the next day.

locations: STA (likely a reference to a government office or network location)
keyFacts: The document details an internal U.S. Attorney's Office process in November 2020 to review and redact data from at least seven of Jeffrey Epstein's electronic devices (phones and iPads identified as 1B71, 1872, 1869, 1884, 1B83, 1867, 1868).

A significant amount of material was withheld as potentially privileged (PP), including 1107 emails from device 1B71, 169 emails and one chat (with Darren Indyke) from device 1884, and 93 emails from device 1869.

Technical difficulties were encountered, such as reports crashing, files appearing empty, and network issues, which hampered the generation of redacted reports for the case team's responsiveness review.
The review focused on specific data types: Chats, SMS, MMS, Emails, Documents, Notes, and Voicemails (VMs).
The correspondence shows a tight timeline, with staff working to complete the privilege review to meet a discovery production deadline of November 9, 2020.
